newsitem.title: UK: PRESS DIGEST - FINANCIAL TIMES - DEC 5.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - FINANCIAL TIMES - DEC 5.

text.p: Prepared for Reuters by The Broadcast Monitoring Company
-- PARIS SUSPENDS THOMSON SALE

The French government has unexpectedly suspended the privatisation of electronics giant Thomson amid widespread public unrest over plans by the prospective buyer, Lagardere, to sell Thomson's consumer electronics arm to the South Korean firm Daewoo. The move follows an announcement from France's independent privatisation commission that it does not approve aspects of the planned sale of Thomson Multimedia to Daewoo. Under Lagardere's plans, Daewoo was to acquire the money-draining division for a nominal 1 French franc.
-- POWER COMPANIES ATTACK LEGALITY OF REFORMS

Britain's privatized electricity companies have raised a legal query over plans by industry regulator Offer to revise the licences they hold, throwing into doubt the planned deregulation of the UK electricity market in 1998. A law firm representing the 12 regional electricity companies in England and Wales and the two Scottish companies has written to the director-general of Offer, Professor Stephen Littlechild, questioning whether the planned changes deal adequately with a number of fundamental legal issues.
-- BANK OF ENGLAND TO CHANGE WAY IT SETS RATES

The Bank of England has announced plans for what it describes as the biggest change to its operation in the money markets for over a century. The bank is to introduce wide-ranging reforms of the way it sets interest rates, as well as widening the range of counterparties with which it trades debt. The proposed changes, which will bring the Bank into line with other European countries such as Germany, have been welcomed by investors.
-- EXCHANGE UNVEILS TIGHTER RULES FOR AIM SHARE MARKET

The London Stock Exchange has announced a series of rule changes to the Alternative Investment Market, the first significant tightening of its rules since the market was launched 18 months ago. Since trading started, 240 companies have joined AIM but some large investors are reported to be concerned about the quality and price of a few new Aim issues. The LSE denies these claims are behind the changes, suggesting they are intended to provide participants with greater access to information.
-- NATWEST TO CUT 10,000 JOBS IN RETAIL DIVISION

National Westminster Bank is to cut the workforce in its retail banking division by more than a quarter over the next five years, a loss of at least 10,000 jobs. Banking unions have been closely involved in discussions about the plans, which are said to include innovative packages for staff who leave the bank. Under NatWest's plans, activities such as account management, lending and telephone inquiries are to be run from 62 centres.
-- REVELLERS MAY HAVE TO SHELL OUT MORE FOR NUTS

Poor weather in California and Iran is set to increase the price of nuts in the UK just in time for Christmas. Pistachio nuts have already risen in price by 20 percent after half this year's Iranian crop was affected by bad weather, while a poor Californian crop for the second year running has forced up the price of almonds by 20 percent in the last six weeks. Price intervention by the Turkish government has seen the cost of hazelnuts surge by 35 percent since August.
-- CELLNET INVESTS 1 BILLION STG IN NETWORK

Mobile phone company Cellnet has announced plans to invest a further 1 billion stg on its network. The investment will go on extending its UK digital network to cover up to 80 percent of the country. Cellnet, the second-largest mobile phone operator in the UK, has already spent 1 billion stg in its analog and digital networks. The company plans to launch advanced "third generation" services from 2001 onwards.
-- SCANDEX LIKELY TO BE WOUND UP IN DENMARK

The High Court in London has adjourned the hearing of a winding-up petition on the Danish currency-trading company Scandex Capital Management, forcing attention back onto parallel insolvency proceedings in Copenhagen. Hundreds of UK-based customers lost money in Scandex, prompting action from the Securities and Investments Board. But the High Court decision now means that full responsibility for the winding up of Scandex will rest with Denmark.
-- INTEREST IN INTERNET FUELS SPATE OF TAKEOVER ACTIVITY

The information technology sector in Europe has seen a 40 percent increase in mergers and acquisitions this year. According to mergers and acquisitions specialist Broadview Associates, the value of the deals totalled 42.9 billion stg, following an explosion of interest in the Internet. Broadview also reports that the telecom sector is restructuring on a world-wide basis, "with some of the largest deals ever".
-- IBM LAUNCHES 100-YEAR BOND TO RAISE 850 MILLION

IBM has launched the largest "century bond" issue ever, with the offer of 850 million in 100-year bonds. The move follows a trend among companies to seize on the current attraction to US investors of higher-yield investments. A total of 4.3 billion has been launched in 100-year bonds by 21 companies, 3.6 billion of which has been launched since last November. IBM intends to use the proceeds of its issue for general corporate purposes, including repaying short-term debt.
